title: Conor McGregor tells Dana White to book fight against Frankie Edgar and will give purse to charity
text:
Conor McGregor called on Dana White to organise his return to UFC for December against Frankie Edgar, as both fighters tweeted they are keen to make the fight happen.

In a brief exchange on Twitter, McGregor responded to a UFC tweet wishing Edgar a happy birthday saying 'Happy birthday Frankie, see you in December.'

Edgar, who turned 38, responded 'Thanks pal, I said yes already it's on you and Dana White to make it happen' - McGregor agreed and then shocked fans, saying: 'There you go White, make the bout. Give my purse to charity.'

Conor McGregor has not fought in the Octagon since his loss to Khabib in October 2018

Frankie Edgar boasts a MMA record of 23-7-1 and lost his last fight to Max Holloway in July

Both fighters called on UFC President Dana White to make the fight happen in December

McGregor, who is currently on bail after allegedly punching a man at a Dublin pub in April, has not fought in the Octagon since his defeat to Khabib Nurmagomedov at UFC 229 in October 2018.

A bust-up between both camps followed the fight, leading to McGregor being banned for six months by the Nevada State Athletic Commission.

But the 31-year-old admitted in a recent interview that he was keen to return to action, and a match-up against Edgar was preferred.

'Who else is top of the list? Frankie Edgar is also up there on the list because he has similarities to Khabib,' McGregor told ESPN's Ariel Helwani.

'He runs on the back foot and shoots on the single leg. I want these sort of similar bouts.

'And also, Frankie has been very respectful. He's always respectful. He said, 'I want to tell my his grandkids I fought Conor McGregor', one day.'

The ball now seems in the court of UFC President White in order for the fight to happen

Edgar boasts a 23-7-1 record and lost his last fight at UFC 240 to Max Holloway on a unanimous decision.

'Even though he lost to Max [Holloway] in a very close bout, I don't care,' said McGregor.

'Wins and losses don't matter in this game. It's the stories we are all on and the journeys we are all on.'
description: McGregor, who is currently on bail after allegedly punching a man at a Dublin pub in April, has not fought in the Octagon since his defeat to Khabib Nurmagomedov at UFC 229 in October 2018.
